[[File:Diesel Forces.jpg|thumb|alt=noir image.|An example of dieselpunk art{{cite web|url=http://stefanparis.deviantart.com/gallery/ |title=stefanparis's Gallery |publisher=Stefanparis.deviantart.com |date= |accessdate=2010-05-25}}]] '''Dieselpunk''' is a genre similar to [[steampunk]] that combines the [[aesthetics]] of the diesel-based technology of the [[interwar period]] through to the 1950s with [[Retrofuturism|retro-futuristic]] technology{{cite web|url=http://www.dailydot.com/fandom/dieselpunk-steampunk-beginners-guide/|title=Dieselpunk for beginners: Welcome to a world where the '40s never ended|author=Aja Romano|date=2013-10-08|publisher=[[The Daily Dot]]|accessdate=2014-04-04}}{{ Citation | url=http://www.ottens.co.uk/gatehouse/Gazette%20-%201.pdf|title=Discovering Dieselpunk | last='Piecraft' |first2= Nick |last2=Ottens| journal = The Gatehouse Gazette|issue =Issue 1|date = July 2008|page =3|accessdate=2010-05-23}} and [[Postmodernism|postmodern]] sensibilities.{{cite web|url=http://www.ottens.co.uk/gatehouse/2013/10/whats-in-a-name/|title=What's in a Name?|author=Larry Amyett|date=October 24, 2013|publisher=The Gatehouse|accessdate=June 25, 2015}} Coined in 2001 by game designer Lewis Pollak to describe his role-playing game ''[[Children of the Sun (role-playing game)|Children of the Sun]]'', the term has since been applied to a variety of visual art, music, motion pictures, fiction, and engineering.{{cite web| first=Janicz|last= Krzysztof|title="Chronologia dieselpunku" (in Polish)|url=http://steampunk.republika.pl/chrono04pl.html| year=2008}} ==Origin== The name "dieselpunk" is a derivative of the 1980s [[science fiction]] genre [[cyberpunk]],{{cite web|author=Dellamonica, A.M. |title=Cyberpunk, steampunk and now stitchpunk? Your guide to 11 sci-fi punks |url=http://scifiwire.com/2009/09/guide-to-sci-fi-punks.php |date=2009-09-08 |accessdate=2009-09-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091003195055/http://scifiwire.com/2009/09/guide-to-sci-fi-punks.php |archivedate=2009-10-03 |df= }} and is used to represent the time period – or "[[era]]" – from the interwar period until the 1950s, when [[diesel fuel|diesel]]-based locomotion was the main technological focus of Western culture.{{cite web|author=DW Productions|title=A History of the Diesel Engine|url=http://www.goadvice.com/GreenDCoop/DieselHistory.htm|accessdate=2010-05-19|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/65WHB3TxU?url=http://www.goadvice.com/GreenDCoop/DieselHistory.htm|archivedate=2012-02-17|df=}} The [[Punk ideologies|"-punk" suffix]] attached to the name is representative of the [[counterculture]] nature of the genre with regards to its opposition to contemporary aesthetics. The term also refers to the tongue-in-cheek{{cite web| author = Sheidlower, Jesse | title = Science Fiction Citations | date = March 9, 2005 | url = http://www.jessesword.com/sf/view/327 | accessdate=May 10, 2008}} name given to a similar cyberpunk derivative, "[[steampunk]]," which focuses on science fiction based on industrial steam power and which is often set within the [[Victorian era]].{{cite web|author=Falksen, GD|title=Steampunk 101 |url=http://www.tor.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=blog&id=58009|date=October 7, 2009|publisher=Tor.com|accessdate=2009-10-07}} ==Differences from steampunk== Author [[Scott Westerfeld]] addresses the question of where to draw the line between steampunk and dieselpunk, arguing that his novel ''[[Leviathan (Westerfeld novel)|Leviathan]]'' (2009) qualifies as steampunk despite the fact that the technology it depicts includes [[diesel engine]]s.
I like the word "dieselpunk" if you are doing something like 'Weird [[World War II]]'. I think that makes perfect sense. But to me, [[World War I]] is the dividing point where [[modernity]] goes from being optimistic to being pessimistic. Because when you put the words "machine" and "gun" together, they both change. At that point, [[war]] is no longer about a sense of [[adventure]] and [[chivalry]] and a way of testing your nation's level of manhood; it's become industrial, and horrible. So playing around with that border between optimistic steampunk and a much more pessimistic dieselpunk, which is more about [[Nazism|Nazis]], was kind of interesting to me because early in the war we were definitely kind of on the steampunk side of that.Carrott, Johnson (2013), p. 154
Jennifer McStotts, another author, considers the two genres to be close cousins. She defines steampunk as concerned with the [[Victorian era]], and the shift in technology and energy generation that came with [[industrialisation]]. The genre is primarily concerned with [[Steam engine|steam power]], [[Nikola Tesla|Tesla]], and [[sustainable energy]], while she defines dieselpunk as the genre combining the aesthetic and genre influences of the period of both [[world war]]s.McStotts (2014), p. 170 Academic [[Gary K. Wolfe]] defines the genres by their era of setting. He defines steampunk as the genre primarily set in the Victorian era and dieselpunk as the genre primarily set in the [[interwar period]].Wolfe (2014), p. 65 ==Dieselpunk inspiration== Dieselpunk draws its inspiration from two related sources: the diesel era and a characteristic referred to by dieselpunks as "decodence." According to the web site ''The Gatehouse'', decodence (a [[portmanteau]] of "deco" and "decadence"), "embraces the styles and technologies of the era; it rejoices in a prolonged [[Jazz Age]] ambience characterized by great enthusiasm and hopes about the future."{{cite web|author=Nick Ottens|url=http://www.ottens.co.uk/gatehouse/2010/01/decodence/|title=Decodence|publisher=The Gatehouse|date=January 1, 2010|accessdate=2014-10-12}} The term "diesel era" is a period of time that begins with the start of the [[Interwar period|interbellum era]], which covers the time between the end of [[World War I]] and the start of [[World War II]]. The interbellum era is central to one school of dieselpunk often labeled "Ottensian." In addition to the interbellum period, World War II also plays a major role in dieselpunk, especially in the school of the genre referred to as "Piecraftian." (See "Common themes found in dieselpunk fiction", below.) The exact ending of the diesel era is in some dispute in the dieselpunk community. Depending on the source it ends either at the conclusion of World War II or continues until the early part of the 1950s with the advent of such cultural icons as the [[Golden Age of Television]] and the replacement of [[Big Band]] and [[Swing music]] with [[Rock and Roll]] in popularity.{{citation needed|date=April 2014}} ==As an art movement== Although the term "dieselpunk" was not coined until 2001, a large body of [[Work of art|art]] significant to the development of the genre was produced before that. Artwork (including [[visual arts]], [[music]], [[literature]], and [[architecture]]) created in the dieselpunk style are heavily influenced by elements of the art movements most prevalent in Western culture during the diesel era such as: * Arts – [[Abstract Expressionism]], [[Art Deco]], [[Bauhaus]], [[Raygun Gothic]], [[Constructivism (art)|Constructivism]], [[Cubism]], [[Dada]], [[De Stijl]] ([[Neo-Plasticism]]), [[Futurism]], [[International Style (architecture)|International Style]], [[Surrealism]] * Music – [[Blues]], jazz, [[ragtime]], [[cabaret]], Big Band, swing, [[retro swing]], and [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]] * Literature – [[Symbolism (arts)|Symbolism]], [[Stream of consciousness (narrative mode)|Stream of consciousness]], [[Modernism]], [[Pulp magazine|Pulp]], [[Hardboiled]] Detective, and [[Noir fiction|Noir]] According to Tome Wilson, owner of Dieselpunks website (www. dieselpunks.org), the term was retroactively applied to an already existing trend in literature. An alternative term was "low-brow pop surrealism". Writers of this trend blended traditional tropes and genres, such as [[Pulp magazine|Pulp Adventure]], [[Film noir]], and [[Weird fiction|Weird Horror]], with a contemporary [[Aesthetics|aesthetic]].Wilson (2013), Welcome to the Retro Future In his words: "They were creating a future fueled by the spirit of the [[Jazz Age]]." In their works, the reader could see [[Sam Spade]] in the era of [[smartphone]]s and [[John Dillinger]] use a [[hovercar]] as his [[Crime scene getaway#Vehicle|getaway vehicle]]. They were writing [[cyberpunk]] stories about the era of ''[[The Great Gatsby]]'' (1925). In discussing punk genres, Ted Stoltz defines dieselpunk as the quasifuture from the [[Art Deco]] era. He argues that [[cyberpunk]], steampunk, [[Cyberpunk derivatives#Clockpunk|clockpunk]], [[Cyberpunk derivatives#Atompunk|atompunk]], and [[Biopunk|ribopunk]] are all defined by their connection to their respective technological element. He found this does not apply to other related genres such as [[Cyberpunk derivatives#Other proposed derivatives|elfpunk, mythpunk]], and [[splatterpunk]] where technology plays a minor role.Stoltz (2011), p. 43-44 ===Fiction and literature=== [[Alternate history|Alternative history]] and World War II feature prominently in dieselpunk literature. Examples of other dieselpunk novels are ''Tales of the First Occult War'' by [[Kevin Cooney]], ''[[Fiends of the Eastern Front]]'' by [[David Bishop]], and ''[[Hard Magic: Book 1 of the Grimnoir Chronicles]]'' by New York Times bestselling novelist [[Larry Correia]]. ====Common themes==== A feature that was first identified by the online magazine ''The Flying Fortress'' is that dieselpunk can be divided into two primary themes or styles: Ottensian and Piecraftian.{{cite web | author = themes | title = The Dark Side of Dieselpunk | publisher = Flying Fortress | date = June 4, 2008 | url = http://flyingfortress.wordpress.com/2008/06/04/the-dark-side-of-dieselpunk/ | accessdate = 2010-05-24 }} The dividing line between the two themes is commonly acknowledged as the start of World War II.{{ Citation | url=http://www.ottens.co.uk/gatehouse/Gazette%20-%201.pdf|title=Discovering Dieselpunk | last='Piecraft' |first2= Nick |last2=Ottens| journal = The Gatehouse Gazette|issue =Issue 1|date = July 2008|page =4|accessdate=2010-05-23}} One theme, named "Piecraftian" after its proponent author "[[Piecraft]]", focuses on the aesthetics of the world wars and speculates on how human [[culture]] could theoretically cease to evolve due to constant, widespread warfare. According to Ottens and Piecraft this theme continues the aesthetics of the diesel era into later periods of history by describing a world where survival (largely based on a reliance on diesel power) is placed above aesthetical evolution (as seen in such dystopian movies as [[Mad Max]]{{ Citation | url=http://www.ottens.co.uk/gatehouse/Gazette%20-%201.pdf|title=Discovering Dieselpunk | last='Piecraft' |first2= Nick |last2=Ottens| journal = The Gatehouse Gazette|issue =Issue 1|date = July 2008|page =9|accessdate=2010-05-23}}). A second theme, named "Ottensian" after its proponent author Nick Ottens, focuses on a setting where the decadent aesthetics and [[utopian]] [[philosophies]] of the American "[[Roaring Twenties]]" continued to evolve unhindered by war or economic collapse. Ottensian dieselpunk [[fiction]] is primarily concerned with a positive vision of technology, where the utopian ideals predicted by the World's Fairs of the times came to light.{{ Citation | url=http://www.ottens.co.uk/gatehouse/Gazette%20-%201.pdf|title=Discovering Dieselpunk | last='Piecraft' |first2= Nick |last2=Ottens| journal = The Gatehouse Gazette|issue =Issue 1|date = July 2008|page =7|accessdate=2010-05-23}} As a result Ottensian dieselpunk incorporates "an enthusiasm for the predictions about the future,"{{cite web|title=The Two Flavors of Dieselpunk|author=Nick Ottens|url=http://www.ottens.co.uk/gatehouse/2008/05/the-two-flavors-of-dieselpunk/|publisher=The Gatehouse|date=May 15, 2008|accessdate=2014-10-12}} and often shares elements with [[retro-futurism]].{{ Citation | url=http://www.ottens.co.uk/gatehouse/Gazette%20-%201.pdf|title=Discovering Dieselpunk | last='Piecraft' |first2= Nick |last2=Ottens| journal = The Gatehouse Gazette|issue =Issue 1|date = July 2008|page =5|accessdate=2010-05-23}} ===Gaming=== Dieselpunk features prominently in the gaming industry, in both tabletop [[role-playing games]] and computer and console [[video games]]. Dieselpunk [[video game]] titles have been extremely prominent in recent years, with the success of the popular ''[[Fallout (series)|Fallout]]'' (1997), and ''[[BioShock]]'' (2007) series of games.{{cite web|url=http://www.brighthub.com/video-games/pc/articles/67680.aspx |title=Top 10 Steampunk and Dieselpunk Games for the PC|author=sinisterporpoise, edited & published by Michael Hartman| publisher=Bright Hub |date=March 30, 2010 |accessdate=2010-05-25}} Sven Schmalfuss feels that ''BioShock'' can be defined as both retro-futuristic [[biopunk]] and dieselpunk.Schmalfuss (2012), p. 94 World War II is also a popular theme in dieselpunk games. One of the more prominent of these was Activision's ''[[Return to Castle Wolfenstein]]'', as well as the sequel game to the 2009 game ''[[Wolfenstein (2009 video game)|Wolfenstein]]'', ''[[Wolfenstein: The New Order]]'', which takes place in an alternate 1960s Europe where the Nazis had won World War II. The game features many dieselpunk style weapons and robots, as the Nazis had focussed more on scientific and military development than social development. Other games set in dieselpunk versions of the World War II era include ''[[Crimson Skies]]'' (1998 board game, 2000 videogame), ''[[Command & Conquer: Red Alert]]'' (1996), and ''[[Sine Mora]]'' (2012).{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/5827659/a-diesel+punk-shootem-up-sure-why-not?tag=grasshopper-manufacture/|title=A Diesel-Punk Shoot'em Up? Sure, Why Not.|author=Brian Ashcraft |date=August 4, 2011|accessdate=2011-08-19}} ===Cinema and television=== With regard to moving pictures, dieselpunk combines the tropes, character archetypes, and settings of diesel era fiction genres such as Serial Adventure, Noir,{{cite book|author=Conrad, Mark T.|title= The Philosophy of Neo-Noir|location= Lexington|publisher= The University Press of Kentucky|date= February 2009|isbn= 0813191815}} Pulp, and War with postmodern storytelling techniques and cinematography. Famous inspirations for dieselpunk cinema include ''[[Metropolis (1927 film)|Metropolis]]'' (1927) and ''[[Things To Come]]'' (1936), thanks to their period visions of [[utopian]] culture and technology. Even the popular film ''[[Star Wars (film)|Star Wars]]'' (1977) has been noted as having strong dieselpunk influences, as it drew heavily on pulp and [[World War II]] iconography but mixed them with futuristic settings.{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/geekdad/2008/04/right-on-the-he/|title=Ancient Weapons and Hokey Religions: Steampunk Star Wars|publisher=Wired.com|author=Vincent Janoski |date=April 15, 2008 |accessdate=2010-05-31|quote=It's already pretty clear that Lucas was drawing from the dieselpunk styling of WWII ...}} Some commonly referenced examples of dieselpunk cinema include: * The [[neo-noir]] movie ''[[Blade Runner]]'' (1982), though widely labeled as [[cyberpunk]], may also be described as dieselpunk due its strong borrowings from Film Noir.{{Cite book | last = Conrad | first = Mark T. | title = The Philosophy of Neo-Noir | publisher = [[University Press of Kentucky]] | date = February 2009 | location = Lexington | isbn = 0813191815}} *''[[Brazil (1985 film)|Brazil]]'' (1985) * ''[[The Rocketeer (film)|The Rocketeer]]'' (1991) *''[[Dark City (1998 film)|Dark City]]'' (1998) *[[Tim Burton]]'s movie ''[[Batman (1989 film)|Batman]]'' (1989) has also been referred to as a dieselpunk movie. *''[[Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow]]'' (2004){{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0346156/trivia|title=Trivia for Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow|publisher=[[Internet Movie Database]]|accessdate=2010-05-28|quote=While set in a "real" New York City, the history is obviously changed. [[The Wizard of Oz (1939 film)|The Wizard of Oz (1939)]] and [[Wuthering Heights (1939 film)|Wuthering Heights (1939)]] references put the year at 1939. Despite being 1939, there is no sign of Germany preparing for war. There is also no sign that America is in the grips of an economic depression. All-in-all, not only is the technology "fantasized", but the entire history is idealized as well.}} *''[[The Sky Crawlers (film)|The Sky Crawlers]]'' (2008) *''[[Captain America: The First Avenger]]'' (2011), whose imagery has been described as having a "dieselpunk quality"{{cite web| author=Neil Marcus, |title=Captain America is hokey, pulpy fun ... no more, no less|url=http://www.indyweek.com/artery/archives/2011/07/21/captain-america-is-hokey-pulpy-fun-no-more-no-less|date=2011-07-21|accessdate=2011-07-23}} *The film ''[[Sucker Punch (2011 film)|Sucker Punch]]'' (2011), directed by [[Zack Snyder]], includes dieselpunk-inspired adventures{{cite web | url = http://lindsaykitson.com/2012/05/15/5-essential-dieselpunk-movies/ | title = 6 Essential Dieselpunk Movies | last = Kitson | first = Lindsay | publisher = Lindsay Kitson, Dieselpunk Author | date = May 15, 2012}}{{cite web | url = http://chroniclesofharriet.com/2012/05/24/punk-101-steampunk-dieselpunk-and-a-three-year-old-genius/ | title = PUNK 101: Steampunk, Dieselpunk and a Three Year Old Genius! | last = Ojetade | first = Balogun | publisher = Chronicles of Harriet | date = May 24, 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://www.steamgeekspodcast.com/blog/2011/04/steam-geeks-episode-07 |title=Episode 07: Dieselpunk! |author=The [[League of STEAM]] |publisher=S.T.E.A.M.Geeks Podcast |date=April 7, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140506021735/http://www.steamgeekspodcast.com/blog/2011/04/steam-geeks-episode-07 |archivedate=2014-05-06 |df= }} with the protagonist Babydoll and her team infiltrating a bunker protected by clockwork World War I German soldiers, etc., mixing many retro, fantastic and sci-fi elements. *''[[Mad Max: Fury Road]]'', while not a true dieselpunk film, has many dieselpunk elements in it.{{cite web| author=Aja Romano, | title='Mad Max: Fury Road' is not steampunk—it's dieselpunk |url=http://www.dailydot.com/parsec/mad-max-fury-road-dieselpunk/|date=2015-06-01|accessdate=2016-08-05}} ===Visual art=== According to an article titled "Dieselpunk: Love Affair with a Machine", published in the online magazine ''Dark Roasted Blend'', in dieselpunk [[art]] "takes an interest in various bizarre machines, full of esoteric levers, cracked-glass meters – all visually intense and pretty sinister-looking, when photographed."{{cite web|url=http://www.darkroastedblend.com/2008/12/dieselpunk.html|title=Dieselpunk: Love Affair with a Machine |author=A. Abrams|publisher=Dark Roasted Blend|date = December 14, 2008|accessdate=2010-05-24}} The article references Japanese artist [[Shunya Yamashita]]'s having created one of the definitive examples of dieselpunk art with his work ''I Can't Explain.''{{cite web|last=Bowkett |first=Giles |url=http://gilesbowkett.blogspot.com/2008/12/shunya-yamashita-i-cant-explain.html |title=Giles Bowkett: Shunya Yamashita: I Can't Explain |publisher=Gilesbowkett.blogspot.com |date=2008-12-28 |accessdate=2010-05-25}} The article also references Kow Yokoyama as a dieselpunk artist with his figurine series titled ''Maschinen Krieger.''{{cite web|url=http://www.maschinenkrueger.com/joomla/ |title=Maschinen Krueger Home |publisher=Maschinenkrueger.com |date= |accessdate=2010-05-25}} Other prominent artists in the dieselpunk movement include: Alexey Lipatov,{{cite web|url=http://lipatov.deviantart.com/ |title=Lipatov on DeviantArt |publisher=Lipatov.deviantart.com |date= |accessdate=2010-05-25}} Stefan Prohaczka, ixlrlxi,{{cite web|url=http://600v.deviantart.com/ |title=600v on DeviantArt |publisher=600v.deviantart.com |date=2010-05-21 |accessdate=2010-05-25}}{{cite web |url=http://www.dieselpunks.org/profiles/blogs/interview-ixlrlxi|title=Icons of Dieselpunk: ixlrlxi, Master artist of the Streamline style|author=Tome Wilson |date=July 9, 2009|accessdate=2010-05-29}} Keith Thompson,{{cite web |url=http://www.dieselpunks.org/forum/topics/interview-keith-thompson|title=Icons of Dieselpunk: Keith Thompson, Mechnical [sic] Art Genius|author=Tome Wilson |date=June 4, 2009|accessdate=2010-05-29}} Rob Schwager,{{cite web|url=http://robschwager.com/ |title=robschwager.com |publisher=robschwager.com |date= |accessdate=2010-05-25}} and Sam Van Olffen.{{cite web|last=Wilson |first=Tome |url=http://www.dieselpunks.org/profiles/blogs/interview-sam-van-olffen |title=INTERVIEW – Sam Van Olffen |publisher=Dieselpunks |date=2009-08-27 |accessdate=2010-05-25}}{{cite web |url=http://io9.com/5319123/wwii-leaders-get-a-dieselpunk-makeover |title=WWII Leaders Get a Dieselpunk Makeover |publisher=io9.com |author=Lauren Davis |date=Jul 21, 2009 |accessdate=2010-05-31}}{{cite web |url=http://theawesomer.com/art-ww2-dieselpunk/20476/ |title=Art: WW2 Dieselpunk |publisher=The Awesomer |accessdate=2010-06-01}} ==As a subculture== A person defined as a dieselpunk draws inspiration and entertainment from the aesthetics of the diesel era to achieve independence from contemporary aesthetics by blending the literature, artwork, [[fashion]], grooming styles, modes of personal transportation, music, and technology of the diesel era with contemporary sensibilities. Part of dieselpunk's postmodern nature can be seen in the important role that the [[internet]] as a tool of international communication plays in its development. In addition to two prominent dieselpunk [[online]] communities, ''Dieselpunks''{{cite web|url=http://www.dieselpunks.org/ |title=Dieselpunk + Steampunk Culture |publisher=Dieselpunks |date= |accessdate=2010-05-25}} and ''The Gatehouse's'' "Smoking Lounge",{{cite web|author=Nick Ottens |url=http://www.ottens.co.uk/lounge/ |title=Smoking Lounge |publisher=Ottens.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2010-05-25}} there are a growing number of online magazines dedicated to the genre including ''The Flying Fortress'',{{cite web|url=http://flyingfortress.wordpress.com/ |title=The Flying Fortress |publisher=Flyingfortress.wordpress.com |date= |accessdate=2010-05-25}} ''Dizelpanki''{{cite web|url=http://community.livejournal.com/dieselpunk/ |title=Дизельпанки |publisher=Community.livejournal.com |date= |accessdate=2010-05-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110309053842/http://community.livejournal.com/dieselpunk/ |archivedate=2011-03-09 |df= }} and several blogs which are simply titled "Dieselpunk".{{cite web|url=http://dieselpunk44.blogspot.com/ |title=Dieselpunk |publisher=Dieselpunk44.blogspot.com |date=1915-08-29 |accessdate=2010-05-25}}{{cite web|url=http://dieselpunks.blogspot.com/ |title=Dieselpunk |publisher=Dieselpunks.blogspot.com |date= |accessdate=2010-05-25}} Another active online magazine covering the dieselpunk movement is ''Vintage Future: Dieselpunk'',{{cite web|last=Rowan |first=Arthur S. |url=http://vintage-future.blogspot.com/search/label/dieselpunk |title=Vintage Future: dieselpunk |publisher=Vintage-future.blogspot.com |date= |accessdate=2010-05-25}} which describes itself as "Retro-futuristic resources from the golden era." While there are many websites dedicated to the history of the diesel era, a growing number of sites are dedicated to topics that tie directly into dieselpunk. One such website of note is ''RetroTimes Production'',{{cite web |url=http://www.dieselpunks.org/profiles/blogs/interview-carmen-johnson-of|title=Icons of Dieselpunk: Carmen Johnson of RetroTimes Productions|author=Tome Wilson |date=March 19, 2010|accessdate=2010-05-29}} which is an independent film production company dedicated to creating documentaries about "retro living, retro design, and retro style." A few sites are springing up that have a retro pulp feel as well, including ''Captain Spectre and The Lightning Legion'',{{cite web |url=http://www.dieselpunks.org/profiles/blogs/interview-pulp-artist|title=Icons of Dieselpunk: Pulp Artist / Creator Tom Floyd|author=Tome Wilson |date=July 31, 2009|accessdate=2010-05-29}} which is an online comic written and drawn in the classic serial [[pulp magazine|pulp fiction]] style of the diesel era, and ''Thrilling Tales of the Downright Unusual'',{{cite web|url=http://thrilling-tales.webomator.com/ |title=Thrilling Tales of the Downright Unusual: Illustrated Interactive Fiction from Retropolis and Beyond |publisher=Thrilling-tales.webomator.com |date= |accessdate=2010-05-25}} an interactive [[Choose Your Own Adventure]]-style pulp serial. In 2012, World Brews, a craft beer manufacturer in [[Novato, CA]], began producing "Dieselpunk Brew", a beer line (IPA, Porter and Stout) inspired and influenced by the subculture of dieselpunk, and displaying art deco-inspired dieselpunk designs on the labels.{{cite web|url=http://bruguru.com/dieselpunk_porter|title=Dieselpunk Porter Beer Review|author=John Staradumsky|date=August 7, 2013|work=Bruguru.com|accessdate=June 8, 2015}} ===Fashion=== Dieselpunk fashion blends the styles commonly found during the diesel era with contemporary styles to create a fusion of both. The "[[Punk subculture|punk]]" nature of the subculture comes from expressing a more complete presence in public akin to the fashion styles popular during the diesel era such as waistcoats, covered arms, hosiery, styles of shoes, and head wear. Dieselpunk emphasizes the inclusion of such accoutrements to render one's look "complete," in defiance of modern custom. ===Music=== Dieselpunk music, which has roots in the [[Swing revival|neo-swing revival]],{{cite web |url=http://www.dieselpunks.org/profiles/blogs/interview-wolfgang-parker|title=Icons of Dieselpunk: Wolfgang Parker, Pioneer of Punk Swing|author=Tome Wilson |date=May 12, 2010|accessdate=2010-05-25}} combines elements of blues, jazz, ragtime, cabaret, swing, and bluegrass commonly found during the diesel era with contemporary instrumentation, production, and composition.{{cite web |url=http://radioriel.blogspot.com/2010/04/from-library-swing-jazz.html|title=Radio Riel Dieselpunk Channel|accessdate=2010-05-25}} Some commonly referenced examples of dieselpunk bands are: [[Big Bad Voodoo Daddy]],{{cite web |url=http://dieselpunk44.blogspot.com/2010/02/dieselpunk-music.html|title=Dieselpunk Music|author=Larry |date=February 7, 2010|accessdate=2010-05-25}} [[Royal Crown Revue]],{{cite web |url=http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1P2-4418727.html|title=Royal Crown Revue, the Penthouse Playboys and the Nicholas Barron Trio at the Cubby Bear|author=Kevin M. Williams | work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]] |publisher=[[Encyclopedia.com]]|date=October 27, 1997|accessdate=2010-05-31}}{{cite web |url=http://www.tommagazine.com.au/index.php?area=Interviews&pg=38&subarea=38&sel=10687&ttl=Royal%20Crown%20Revue|title= Interviews: Royal Crown Revue|author=Brett Stephens |publisher=Tom Magazine|accessdate=2010-05-31}} [[Squirrel Nut Zippers]],{{cite web|url=http://mammoth.go.com/squirrelnutzippers/ |title=Squirrel Nut Zippers |publisher=[[Mammoth Records]] |quote=''Hot'' was an unexpected hit that placed the Zippers at the head of a retro-swing revival that they didn't understand, much less belong to. For one thing, they didn't really play Swing Music, ''per se''. They played 'Hot Music,' a perpetually evolving, hybrid-stew of Southern roots traditions that one critic aptly tagged, '30s punk.' |accessdate=2010-05-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100910112356/http://mammoth.go.com/squirrelnutzippers/ |archivedate=2010-09-10 |df= }} [[The Brian Setzer Orchestra]], Indigo Swing, Wolfgang Parker, The End Times Spasm Band, [[RPM Orchestra]], [[Big Rude Jake]], and [[Lee Press-on and the Nails]].{{cite web |url=http://www.dieselpunks.org/profiles/blogs/interview-brian-gardner-of|title=Icons of Dieselpunk: Brian Gardner of Swing Goth|author=Tome Wilson |date=January 28, 2010|accessdate=2010-06-03}} There has been growth of a Dieselpunk music referred to as [[electro swing]], which combines the styles of [[Swing music]] with [[Electronica]]. Prominent bands within the Electro-Swing include [[Caravan Palace]], Good Co, and [[:de:Tape Five|Tape Five]]. ==Variants== === Decopunk === Decopunk is a recent subset of Dieselpunk, inspired by the [[Art Deco]] and [[Streamline Moderne]] art styles of the period between the 1920s and 1950s. In an interview{{cite web|title=Rayguns! Steampunk Fiction|url=http://coyotecon.com/transcripts/transcript-rayguns-steampunk-fiction/|work=Interview transcript|date=17 May 2010|accessdate=11 April 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100521043531/http://coyotecon.com/transcripts/transcript-rayguns-steampunk-fiction/|archivedate=21 May 2010}} at CoyoteCon, steampunk author [[Sara M. Harvey]] made the distinctions "... shinier than DieselPunk, more like DecoPunk", and "DieselPunk is a gritty version of Steampunk set in the 1920s–1950s. The big war eras, specifically. DecoPunk is the sleek, shiny very Art Deco version; same time period, but everything is chrome!" === Atompunk === A similar, related pop surrealist art movement, which overlaps with dieselpunk somewhat, is atompunk (sometimes called atomicpunk). Atompunk art relates to the pre-digital period of 1945–1965, including mid-century [[Modernism]], the [[Atomic Age]], [[Jet Age]] and [[Space Age]], [[Communism]] and [[paranoia]] in the USA along with [[Soviet]] styling, [[underground cinema]], [[Googie]] architecture, the [[Sputnik]], [[Project Mercury|Mercury]] and other early [[space program]]s, early [[Cold War]] [[espionage]], [[superhero fiction]] and the rise of the US military/industrial powers.{{cite news | first=Bruce | last=Sterling | title=Here Comes 'Atompunk.' And It's Dutch. So there | url=https://www.wired.com/beyond_the_beyond/2008/12/here-comes-atom/ | date=2008-12-03 | accessdate=2015-06-25 | work=Wired}}{{cite web | first = Cory | last = Doctorow | title = Atompunk: fetishizing the atomic age | url = http://www.boingboing.net/2008/12/03/atompunk-fetishizing.html |publisher=[[Boing Boing]]| date = December 3, 2008 | accessdate = 2010-06-03}} ==See also== * [[Airborne aircraft carrier]] * [[Air pirate]] * [[Alternate history]] * [[Cyberpunk]] * [[Cyberpunk derivatives]] * [[Lowbrow (art movement)]] * [[Pop art]] * [[Postmodernism]] * [[Retro-futurism]] * [[Steampunk]] * [[Submarine aircraft carrier]] * [[Swing revival]] ==Sources== * {{citation | last1=Carrott | first1=James H.| last2=Johnson | first2=Brian David | title=''Vintage Tomorrows: A Historian And A Futurist Journey Through Steampunk Into The Future of Technology'' | chapter= Digging Into the Past| year=2013 | publisher=[[O'Reilly Media]]| isbn=978-1449337957| url =https://books.google.gr/books?id=1XQ6xt25aREC&pg=PA154&dq=dieselpunk+genre&hl=en&sa=X&ei=4dMkVarbJZPXat6pgfAE&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=dieselpunk%20genre&f=false}} * {{citation | last1=McStotts | first1= Jennifer | title=''The Multiple Worlds of Fringe: Essays on the J.J. Abrams Science Fiction Series'' | chapter= Asking the Biopunk Questions:Opposition and Interrogation in Olivia Dunham and Walter Bishop: Notes| year=2014 | publisher=[[McFarland & Company]]| isbn=978-0786475674| url =https://books.google.gr/books?id=q80tBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA170&dq=dieselpunk+genre&hl=en&sa=X&ei=4dMkVarbJZPXat6pgfAE&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=dieselpunk%20genre&f=false}} * {{citation | last1=Schmalfuss | first1= Sven | title=''The Aesthetics of Authenticity: Medial Constructions of the Real'' | chapter= Authentic Bodies: Genome(s) vs. Gender Norms in Oryx and Crake, the Year of the Flood, and BioShock| year=2012 | publisher=transcript Verlag| isbn=978-3839417577| url The '''Eagle Street College''' was an informal literary society established in 1885 at the home of James William Wallace in Eagle Street, [[Bolton]], to read and discuss literary works, particularly the poetry of [[Walt Whitman]], (1819–91). The group subsequently became known as the Bolton Whitman Fellowship or Whitmanites. Its founder members were Wallace, Dr John Johnston and Fred Wild. The group held an annual 'Whitman Day' celebration around the 31 May which was the poet's birthday.<ref name="WWC">{{Citation |title=C.F. Sixsmith Walt Whitman Collection|url=https://archiveshub.jisc.ac.uk/manchesteruniversity/data/gb133-engms1186|publisher=University of Manchester Library| accessdate=2017-09-26}}</ref>
Wallace and Johnston corresponded with Whitman and Johnston visited Whitman at his home in Camden, [[New Jersey]]. Wallace visited Whitman in 1891. Wallace moved to [[Adlington, Lancashire|Adlington]] in the early 1890s and invited Charles Sixsmith to join the group which continued until the death of Wallace in 1926 and in a more modest form after that. After Wallace moved to Adlington in the early 1890s the group continued to meet in each other's homes.<ref name="BM">{{Citation |title=Walt Whitman and Bolton|url=http://www.boltonmuseums.org.uk/bolton-archives/walt-whitman/ |publisher=Bolton Museums|accessdate=2010-09-12 }}</ref> Sixsmith was involved in the annual Whitman celebrations until the late 1930s.<ref name="WWC"/> A plaque marking one of these celebrations can be found in the grounds of [[Rivington Unitarian Chapel]].<ref name="Uni">{{Citation|title=Rivington Unitarian Chapel|url=http://www.unitarian.org.uk/mda/RIVINGTON/|publisher=unitarian.org.uk|accessdate=2010-06-15|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100927065749/http://www.unitarian.org.uk/mda/RIVINGTON/|archivedate=2010-09-27|df=}}</ref>

{{original research|date=April 2016}} {{Infobox food | name = Empanada | image = Empanada - Stu Spivack.jpg | caption = Two empanadas | country = | region = | creator = | course = Appetizer | served = Hot or cold | main_ingredient = [[Pastry]], [[stuffing|filling]] | variations = [[Pastel (food)|Pastel]], [[Pastry]] | no_commons = true }} An '''empanada''' is a type of [[pastry]] baked or fried in Hispanic cultures. The name comes from the Spanish verb {{wikt-lang|es|empanar}}, and literally translates as "enbreaded", that is, wrapped or [[Breading|coated in bread]]. Empanadas are made by folding [[dough]] over a [[stuffing]], which may consist of meat, cheese, corn, or other ingredients. == Origins == Empanadas trace back their origins to the northwest region of Spain, [[Galicia (Spain)|Galicia]].{{cite web | title=Historia de la empanada criolla |url=http://www.produccion-animal.com.ar/temas_historia/76-empanadas.pdf | work=Dra. Susana Barberis |accessdate=8 July 2010}}[[Penelope Casas]] (1982), ''The Food, Wines, and Cheeses of Spain'', Alfred A. Knopf, New York 1982 (p. 52){{cite web | title=Breve historia de la alimentación en Argentina |url=http://www.fac.org.ar/fec/foros/cardtran/gral/Historia.htm | work=Liliana Agrasar |accessdate=8 July 2010}} They first appeared in [[Middle Ages|medieval]] [[Iberian Peninsula|Iberia]] during the time of the [[Al-Andalus|Moorish invasions]]. A cookbook published in [[Catalan language|Catalan]] in 1520, ''Libre del Coch'' by [[Robert de Nola]], mentions empanadas filled with seafood in the recipes for Catalan, Italian, French, and Arabian food.{{cite book|last=Adamson|first=Melitta Weiss|title=Food in medieval times|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|year=2004|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jtgud2P-EGwC&lpg=PA122&ots=9ilNQugLY1&dq=empanada%20arab%20origin&pg=PA125#v=onepage&q=empanadas&f=false|isbn=0-313-32147-7}}{{cite web|url=http://www.florilegium.org/?http%3A//www.florilegium.org/files/FOOD-MANUSCRIPTS/Guisados1-art.html|title=An English translation of Ruperto de Nola's ''Libre del Coch''|author=Lady Brighid ni Chiarain|publisher=Stefan's Florilegium|accessdate=January 31, 2011}} ==By country and region== === Argentina === [[File:Empanadas cordobesas (Argentina) caseras.JPG|thumb|Home made empanadas from Córdoba, Argentina]] [[Argentine cuisine|Argentine]] empanadas are often served during parties and festivals as a starter or main course. Shops specialize in freshly made empanadas, with many flavors and fillings. The [[dough]] is made with [[wheat flour]] and beef [[dripping]]s for the fillings which differs from province to province. Some places use [[Chicken (food)|chicken]], and some places beef (cubed or ground depending on the region) spiced with [[cumin]] and [[paprika]]. Some other fillings are [[onion]], [[boiled egg]], [[olive]]s, or [[raisin]]s. Empanadas can be baked or fried. It also can contain [[ham]], [[Fish (food)|fish]], ''[[humita]]'' ([[sweetcorn]] with [[white sauce]]), or [[spinach]]; a [[fruit]] filling is used to create a [[dessert]] empanada. For the [[Hinterland|interior regions]], they can be spiced with [[Capsicum|peppers]]. In those places (usually [[take-out]] shops) where several types are served, a ''repulgue'', or [[pattern]], is added to the [[pastry]] fold to distinguish the varieties (although it is more common nowadays to burn a letter – an abbreviated indication of the filling – into the dough). In larger cities, empanadas are eaten more as take-away food, sourced from restaurants specializing in this dish. They usually carry dozens of different varieties, which is not the case in [[Argentine Northwest|northern provinces]], where empanadas are usually made at home, with more traditional recipes. During [[Lent]] and [[Easter]], ''empanadas de Cuaresma'' fillings with fish (usually [[Dogfish sharks|dogfish]] or [[tuna]]) are popular.{{cite web|url=http://www.quericavida.com/en/recipes/argentine-atun-empanadas/|title=Argentine Atún Empanadas|accessdate=26 January 2015}} === Belize === [[File:Belize panades.jpg|thumb|Panades in [[Cayo District]], [[Belize]]]] In [[Belize]], empanadas are known as ''panades''. They are made with [[masa]] (corn dough) and typically stuffed with fish, chicken, or beans.{{cite web |title=Belizean Food |url=http://www.belize.com/belize-fast-food |website=Belize.com |publisher=ITM Ltd. |accessdate=1 December 2015 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/6dSyL6UMp?url=http://www.belize.com/belize-fast-food |archive-date=2015-12-02 |dead-url=no |df= }} They are usually deep fried and served with a cabbage or salsa topping. Panades are frequently sold as [[street food]].{{cite book|editor1-last=Kraig|editor1-first=Bruce|editor2-last=Sen|editor2-first=Colleen Taylor|title=Street Food Around the World: An Encyclopedia of Food and Culture|date=2013|publisher=ABC-CLIO|location=Santa Barbara, California|isbn=978-1-59884-954-7|page=72}} === Cape Verde === [[Cape Verde]] cuisine features the [[Pastel (food)|''pastel'']], as well. Cape Verdean ''pastéis'' are often filled with spicy tuna fish. One particular variety, the ''pastel com o diabo dentro'' (literally: Pastel with the devil within), is particularly spicy, and is made with a dough made from sweet potatoes and cornmeal.Hamilton, Cherie. ''Cuisines of Portuguese Encounters'', Hippocrene Books. 2001. === Chile === [[File:Empanada tray.jpg|thumb|left|Chilean-style empanadas]] The empanada is considered the most symbolic food of the country.Eyzaguirre Lyon (1986), p. 24 {{Incomplete short citation|date=June 2018}} [[Salvador Allende]], the President of Chile from 1970 to 1973, emphasized the national character of his political project saying that it would be a "revolution with the flavor of red wine, and the scent of an empanada".{{ill|Gonzalo Martner Fanta|es}}, p. 23 {{Incomplete short citation|date=April 2017}} Eating empanadas, especially the meat ones called "empanadas de pino", becomes more popular during September, the month that Chile celebrates [[Fiestas Patrias (Chile)|las fiestas patrias]] or their independence."La ruta de las empanadas", ''[[La Segunda]]''. 11 September 2012. They are eaten during meals like [[asado]]s or Chilean barbeques, and are accompanied with drinks like [[Chicha|la chicha]] and red wine.The Chilean empanada, This is Chile, November 3, 2009{{better source|date=March 2018}} Meat empanadas ("de pino") are filled with ground beef, fried with white onion and are seasoned with garlic, hard-boiled eggs, olives, and sometimes raisins.[[Eugenio Pereira Salas|Pereira Salas]] (1977), p. 60 {{Incomplete short citation|date=June 2018}} This version is known as the typical baked Chilean empanada,{{cn|date=March 2018}} although it can also be fried. Seafood empanadas are filled with crab, [[clam]]s, [[Concholepas concholepas|sea snails]], or special oysters called [[crassostrea]] and cheese. Different seafood can be used, and they are mixed with chopped white onion.Chile Travel Pulse, March 3, 2017{{better source|date=March 2018}} === Philippines === [[File:Empanada (Philippines).jpg|thumb|Philippine fried empanadas, with ground beef, potatoes, carrots, cheese, and raisins in a thin, crisp crust]] [[Philippine cuisine|Filipino]] empanadas usually contain ground beef, pork or chicken, potatoes, chopped onions, and raisins (somewhat similar to the Cuban ''picadillo'') in a somewhat sweet, wheat flour bread. There are two kinds available: the baked sort and the flaky fried type. To lower costs, potatoes are often added as an extender, while another filling is ''[[kutsay]]'', or [[garlic chives]] (''kutsay'' in [[Cebuano language|Cebuano]] and [[Tagalog language|Tagalog]]; 韭菜 ''kú-chhài'' in [[Lan-nang]]). Empanadas in the northern part of the [[Ilocos]] are different. These usually have savoury fillings of green [[papaya]], [[mung bean]]s, and sometimes chopped Ilocano [[sausage]] (''[[chorizo]]'') and egg yolk.{{cite web |url=http://www.sunstar.com.ph/pampanga/vigan-empanada-and-gastronomic-treats-ilocos |title=Vigan Empanada and the gastronomic treats of Ilocos |author=Ian Ocampo Flora |date=April 23, 2010 |work= |publisher=www.sunstar.com.ph |accessdate=30 December 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100505212143/http://www.sunstar.com.ph/pampanga/vigan-empanada-and-gastronomic-treats-ilocos |archivedate=5 May 2010 |df= }} === Sicily (Italy) === [[File:'Mpanatigghi.JPG|thumb|left|'Mpanatigghi]] The 'Mpanatigghi are stuffed, consisting of halfmoon-shaped [[panzarotti]] filled with a mixture of almonds, walnuts, chocolate, sugar, cinnamon, cloves and minced beef.{{cite news |author=Red. Spe. |title=Quanto è "dolce" Ragusa |newspaper=[[Corriere del Mezzogiorno]] |date=31 July 2013}}{{cite book |author=Giovanni Assenza |title=Miele, garofano, cannella. I profumi dei dolci di Sicilia |publisher=Assenza |date=2014 |isbn=605-030-594-3}}{{cite book |author=Nicky Pellegrino |title=The Food of Love Cookery School |publisher=Hachette UK |date=2013 |isbn=1-4091-3381-8}} These are typical of [[Modica]], in the province of [[Ragusa, Italy|Ragusa]], [[Sicily]]. They are also known as ''impanatiglie'' or ''dolce di carne'' (pasty of meat).{{cite book |author=Monica Cesari Sartoni |title=Mangia italiano. Guida alle specialità regionali italiane |publisher=Morellini Editore |date=2005 |isbn=88-89550-05-8}} They were probably introduced by the Spaniards during their rule in Sicily which took place in the sixteenth century; this is suggested from the etymology of the name which comes from the Spanish "empanadas or empadillas" (empanada), as well as from the somewhat unusual combination of meat and chocolate, which occurs several times in the Spanish cuisine.{{cite book |author=Touring Club of Italy |title=Authentic Sicily |publisher=Touring Editore |date=2005 |isbn=88-365-3403-1}} In past centuries for the preparation of 'mpanatigghi [[game meat]] was used but today beef is used. {{clear}} [[File:Empanadas Venezolanas.jpg|thumb|Venezuelan empanadas]] === United States === Empanadas, mainly based on South American recipes, are widely available in [[New York City]] and throughout [[New Jersey]] from [[food cart]]s, [[food truck]]s, and restaurants.[http://gothamist.com/2014/10/13/nyc_empanada_guide.php "10 Spots To Score Excellent Empanadas In NYC"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160708091422/http://gothamist.com/2014/10/13/nyc_empanada_guide.php |date=2016-07-08 }} by Angely Mercado, ''[[Gothamist]]'', 13 October 2014;
[http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2015/10/09/nyc-food-truck-lunch-empanadas-from-la-sonrisa-empanadas/ "NYC Food Truck Lunch: Empanadas From La Sonrisa Empanadas"] by Perry R., [[CBS New York]], 9 October 2015 Empanadas are usually found in U.S. areas with a large Hispanic population, like Miami, [[San Antonio]], {{cite web|title=The 15 Best Places for Empanadas in San Antonio|url=https://foursquare.com/top-places/san-antonio/best-places-empanadas|website=FourSquare|accessdate=January 4, 2017}}{{cite web|last1=Rice|first1=Janae|title=Finding Empanadas in SA|url=http://www.sacurrent.com/Flavor/archives/2014/04/08/finding-empanadas-in-sa|work=[[San Antonio Current]]|accessdate=January 4, 2017}} and [[Los Angeles]].{{cite web|last1=Chabala|first1=Tracy|title=5 Great Baked Empanadas in Los Angeles|url=http://www.laweekly.com/restaurants/5-great-baked-empanadas-in-los-angeles-2895481|work=[[LA Weekly]]|accessdate=January 4, 2017}} ==See also== * {{portal-inline|Food}} * [[List of stuffed dishes]] * [[Meat pie]] * [[Turnover (food)]] * [[Çiğ börek]] == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * {{commons category-inline|Empanadas}} * [http://latinfood.about.com/od/pictoralhowtoarticles/ss/howtoempanada.htm How to Make Empanadas]—Step-by-step guide with pictures on how to make empanadas. {{Pastries}} {{Street food}} [[Category:Caribbean cuisine]] [[Category:Cuisine of the Southwestern United States]] [[Category:Latin American cuisine]] [[Category:Portuguese cuisine]] [[Category:Savoury pies]] [[Category:Spanish cuisine]] [[Category:Mexican cuisine]] [[Category:Galician cuisine]] [[Category:Stuffed dishes]] [[Category:National dishes]]

{{Infobox artist | bgcolour = #FBF5DF | name = Fausto Zonaro | image = Zonaro.jpg | imagesize = | caption = Self-portrait | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date|1854|9|18|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Masi, Veneto|Masi]], [[Padua]], [[Austrian Empire]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1929|7|19|1854|9|18|df=y}} | death_place = [[Sanremo]], Italy | nationality = till 1866 [[Austrians|Austrian]] from 1866 [[Italians|Italian]] | field = painting | training = | movement = [[Orientalism]]<ref>http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/n.php?n=a-century-long-story-of-turkish-art-2010-03-08</ref> | works = | patrons = | influenced by = | influenced = | awards = }} '''Fausto Zonaro''' (18 September 1854 – 19 July 1929) was an Italian painter, best known for his [[Realism (arts)|Realist]] style paintings of life and history of the [[Ottoman Empire]].
==Life==
===Young life and early art career=== [[Image:Ertugrulsuvarialayi zonaro.jpg|thumb|upright|250px|left|''Il reggimento imperiale di Ertugrul sul ponte di Galata'' (''The Imperial Regiment of the Ertugrul on the [[Galata Bridge]]'')]] Fausto Zonaro was born in [[Masi, Province of Padua|Masi]], a municipality in the [[Province of Padua]], then part of the [[Austrian Empire]]. He was the eldest child of the mason Maurizio and his wife Elisabetta Bertoncin. Maurizio intended that his son should also be a mason, yet at a young age, Fausto showed a great ability at [[drawing]].<ref name =FBIO>http://www.faustozonaro.it/biografia.html</ref> With his parents’ consent, he enrolled first in the Technical Institute in [[Lendinara]], then in the [[Cignaroli Academy]] in [[Verona]] under [[Napoleone Nani]]. Fausto opened a small art school and studio in [[Venice]], but traveled often to [[Naples]] as well. He felt no clear direction in his life at that time.
He actively displayed works in exhibition and gained respect of critics. He painted mainly [[Genre painting|genre]] works in oil and watercolor. In 1883 at Milan, he exhibited: ''Le rivelatrici napoletane''; ''Da [[Castel Sant'Elmo|Sant'Elmo]]'', and ''Al [[Pincian Hill|Pincio]]''; in Rome, the canvases ''Passa la vacca''; ''La sofferente''; ''Le cucitrici napoletane'', and ''Il saponaro''. In 1884, at Turin: ''Tempesta''; ''Primo nato''; ''Primo tuono'', and the ''[[Mount Zoccolaro|Zoccolaro]] of Naples''; and in 1887 at Venice: ''In attesa''; ''Al Redentoretto'', and ''Lavoratrice di perle''. La casa Camerini of Padua once possessed a ''banditore''; and two canvases: ''I pigiatori'' and ''In medio stat virtus''.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=Zz0bAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false ''Dizionario degli Artisti Italiani Viventi: pittori, scultori, e Architetti.''], by [[Angelo de Gubernatis]]. Tipe dei Successori Le Monnier, 1889, page 562.</ref> [[File:Fausto Zonaro - Amusement at Göksu - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|''On the [[Göksu]]'']] The turning point in Zonaro’s career occurred however in 1891, when he fell in love with Elisabetta Pante, a pupil of his in Venice, And together they traveled to Istanbul, capital of the [[Ottoman Empire]]. They were partly inspired by [[Edmondo de Amicis]]’ orientalist travel book ''Constantinopoli''.<ref name =FBIO/>
===Istanbul===
In 1892, Zonaro and Pante married, and lived in the Istanbul neighborhood of [[Beyoğlu|Pera]].
In Istanbul, over time he gained patronage in aristocratic circles. [[Munir Pasha]], the Minister of Protocol, who invited him to visit [[Yıldız Palace]] and meet the prestigious local artist [[Osman Hamdi Bey]]. He was employed in teaching painting to the Pasha's wife, and in this way Zonaro and Pante got to know the important artistic figures of Istanbul of that time. In 1896 he was nominated as the [[court painter]] ([[Ottoman Turkish language|Ottoman Turkish]]: ''Ressam-ı Hazret-i Şehriyari'') thanks to the intervention of the [[Russian Empire|Russian]] ambassador who had presented the ruling sultan [[Abdulhamid II]] with Zonaro’s work ''Il reggimento imperiale di Ertugrul sul ponte di Galata'' (in English: ''The Imperial Regiment of the Ertugrul on the Galata Bridge''), which Abdulhamid II had then purchased.
[[Image:Conquest of Constantinople, Zonaro.jpg|thumb|left|''[[Mehmed II]] and the [[Ottoman Army]] approaching [[Constantinople]], transporting a giant bombard'' by Zonaro.]]
<!-- This painting is of the crew of the Ottoman warship ''[[Ottoman frigate Ertuğrul|Ertugrul]]'' which had just been sent off on a visit to [[Empire of Japan|Japan]]. NB: The years don't fit this guess; a cavalry regiment of the same name as the ship. -->The Sultan later commissioned from Zonaro a series of paintings depicting events in the life of the 15th-century Ottoman sultan, [[Mehmed II]]. Holding the position of court painter, Zonaro viewed himself as the successor to the Venetian painter [[Gentile Bellini]], who had been commissioned by Mehmed II to paint his portrait over 300 years earlier.<ref>''Constantinople - City of the World’s Desire 1453-1924'' by Philip Mansel</ref> [[File:Fausto Zonaro - Kabak Taşıyan Genç Kız , Young Girl Carrying a Pumpkin - Google Art Project.jpg|thumbnail|Fausto Zonaro Young Girl Carrying a Pumpkin, 1889]] Also during his stay in Istanbul, Zonaro witnessed the [[Day of Ashura]] processions carried out by the [[Shia]] Muslims on the tenth of Muharram, and it was the procession of [[Tatbir]] that inspired him to paint his renowned painting ''10th of Muharram'', it was reported that Zonaro said "After witnessing the horripilating procession (of Tatbir) I wish I were able to meet this man they mourn for". The "man" Zonaro speaks of indicates to the oppressed grandson of the Muslim prophet Mohammed, [[Hussein ibn Ali]].
===Return to Italy=== Zonaro remained in Istanbul until 1909, when he returned to Italy following the [[Young Turk Revolution]] that overthrew his patron Abdulhamid II and the shift to constitutional monarchy. There would be no Ottoman court painter after him.<ref name =FBIO/> He settled in [[Sanremo]] where he continued to paint small works depicting the [[Italian Riviera]] and the nearby [[French Riviera]] until his death.
In 1920 he separated from his wife and began living with his daughter. Nine years later, he died. He is buried in the Foce Cemetery in Sanremo. On his gravestone, underneath an Ottoman ''[[tughra]]'', it states that Zonaro was the court painter of the Ottoman Empire.<ref name =OSAR>http://www.os-ar.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=166</ref>
==Artistic work and reputation==
Zonaro painted [[portrait]]s, [[landscape art|landscapes]] and [[history painting|historical paintings]]. It is claimed that “Zonaro was one of those who made a major contribution to the development of western style art in Turkey.”<ref name =OSAR/> He was a prolific artist who created hundreds of works, most of which are of the Ottoman Empire. An exhibition of his work in Florence in 1977 "received wide acclaim in the art world".<ref name =OSAR/>
Today, most of Zonaro’s works remain in Istanbul, and many of them are on display in the city’s leading museums. His pictures can be found in the state museums of [[Topkapı Palace]], [[Dolmabahçe Palace]] and the [[Istanbul Military Museum]]. Zonaro’s works can also be found in the private [[Sakıp Sabancı Museum]]<ref>http://muze.sabanciuniv.edu/collection/collection.php?lngCollectionID=12&bytLanguageID=2</ref> and [[Pera Museum]]. Also, a number of them belong to private collectors in Turkey.<ref name =OSAR/>
==Gallery==
Some of Zonaro's paintings are in the Pera Art Museum in Istanbul (including ''Daughter of the English Ambassador Riding in a Palanquin'') and the Istanbul Museum of Modern Art. {{Clear}}
