{{refimprove|date=March 2014}} '''Yissum Research Development Company''' is the [[technology transfer]] company of the [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]].<ref>[http://www.biojerusalem.org.il/database_tto.asp?ID=1 Biojerusalem Database: Yissum Research Development Company]</ref> Yissum was founded in 1964 to market ideas and innovation of university researchers and employees.
In 2005, Yissum ranked second in commercial profit earnings among Israel's academic institutions, the first being the [[Weizmann Institute of Science]]'s company, Yeda Research and Development.<ref>[http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/business/hebrew-university-patent-company-yissum-enjoys-record-revenues-royalties-in-2004-1.158190 Hebrew University patent company Yissum enjoys record revenues, royalties in 2004, [[Haaretz]]]</ref>
Yissum has founded more than 80 start-up companies. Products brought to market by Yissum are sold in billions of dollars annually. Yissum has registered more than 8,000 individual patent applications in more than 2,200 patent families and signed over 700 license agreements.
Yissum has signed collaboration agreements with [[Cornell]], [[UCBerkeley]], [[Caltech]], [[Carnegie Mellon University]], [[Children's Medical Center]], [[Columbia University]], [[Harvard University]], [[Johns Hopkins University]], [[MIT]], [[Mayo Clinic]], [[Michigan State University]], [[NYU]], [[Northwestern University]], [[Rockefeller University]], [[Stanford University]] and other educational institutions.
==History== Yissum Research Development Company was founded in 1964 to protect and market the Hebrew University’s intellectual property. Products generate $2 billion in annual sales. Yissum has registered over 8,100 patents covering 2,300 inventions; licensed 700 technologies and formed 80 companies. Yissum’s business partners include Syngenta, Monsanto, Roche, Novartis, Microsoft, Johnson & Johnson, Merck, Intel and Teva.<ref>[http://jewishbusinessnews.com/2013/09/16/makhteshim-agan-and-yissum-partner-to-develop-a-novel-method-for-protecting-plants-using-yeast-isolated-from-strawberry-leaves/ Mahkteshim Agan and Yissu partner to develop a novel method for protecting plants using yeast isolated from strawberry leaves]</ref>
In Israel, [[technology transfer]] entities are organized as companies, unlike the United States. In the United States technology transfer operations only began after the [[Bayh–Dole Act]] in 1982. The formation of companies for doing technology transfer greatly influences the operation of technology transfer.
Yissum is a for-profit company which is fully owned by the Hebrew University which is a not-for-profit entity. This makes Yissum a non-typical entity which unlike regular for-profit companies has additional goals.
In 2005, Yissum developed a TTM solution considered the leading solution for universities in Israel. Yissum maintains ongoing contacts with [[Association of University Technology Managers]] which allows exchange of technologies, ideas, methods of work and many other valuable information.
In 2014, QLight Nanotech, a subsidiary of Yissum partly owned by Merck, opened an R&D facility in [[Jerusalem]] for developing LED lighting and flat-panel display products using semiconductor nanocrystal materials.<ref>[http://www.jpost.com/Business/Business-News/Merck-backed-QLight-opens-new-Jerusalem-nanotech-site-328111 Merck-backed QLight opens new Jerusalem nanotech site]</ref>
==Start up companies== * QLight Nanotech - A subsidiary of Yissum, is a start up partly owned by [[Merck KGaA]]. In 2013, QLight opened a new facility in Jerusalem to develop LED lighting and flat-panel display products using semiconductor nano-crystal materials.<ref>[http://www.jpost.com/Business/Business-News/Merck-backed-QLight-opens-new-Jerusalem-nanotech-site-328111 Merck-backed QLight opens new Jerusalem nanotech site]</ref> * [[Mobileye|MobilEye]] <ref>{{cite news|title=Mobileye, a Maker of Automated Driving Systems, Raises $400 Million|url=https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2013/07/07/mobileye-a-maker-of-automated-driving-systems-raises-400-million/?_r=1|newspaper=New York Times|date=July 7, 2013}}</ref> * BriefCam ([[Video Synopsis]])<ref>[http://www.jewishpress.com/news/israel-hi-tech-firm-helped-capture-boston-bomber-terrorists/2013/04/29/ Israel Hi-Tech Firm Helped Capture Boston Bombers]</ref> * HumanEyes * [[OrCam device|OrCam]] <ref>[https://www.theverge.com/2013/6/5/4400990/orcam-glasses-read-aloud OrCam's $2,500 augmented reality glasses speak words aloud, help the visually impaired 'see']</ref> * [[Ex Libris Group]]<ref name=THE>[http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/features/instant-access-distant-library/98933.article Instant access, distant library], Helena Flusfeder, Times Higher Education; 13 November 1995</ref>
==Products brought to market by Yissum== * [[Rivastigmine|Exelon]] - A cholinesterase inhibitor, a type of medicine prescribed for people in the early or middle stages of Alzheimer's disease. Invented by Marta Weinstock-Rosin. * [[Doxil]] - additional information can be found also at [[Doxorubicin]] - For the treatment of patients with ovarian cancer. Invented by Yechezkal Barenholz and Alberto Gabizon. * [[Chlorhexidine|PerioChip]] - For reduction of pocket depth in patients with chronic preiodontitis. Invented by Michael Friedman, Michael Sela and Doron Steinberg * [[Cherry tomato]]es and long shelf life tomatoes - Invented by Haim Rabinowitch and Nachum Kedar. * Hybrid peppers - Invented by Yonatan Elkind. * LO2 Eye Drops - Invented by Shabtay Dikstein * Cationorm - For relief to patients suffering from dry eye symptoms. Invented by Simon Benita. * UV-Pearl Technology - Invented by David Avnir

Haris PašovićCredits, ''[http://www.filmfestival-goeast.de/index.php?article_id=228&clang=1&mode=film&event_id=1941]'' |starring = |studio = [[Space Productions]] |distributor = Gramofon |released = {{Film date|2005|06|22|df=y}} |runtime = 30 minutes |country = [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] |language = [[Bosnian language|Bosnian]] |budget = |gross = }} '''''À propos de Sarajevo''''' is a name of a documentary written and directed by [[Haris Pašović]].[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0488039/ IMDB: ''À propos de Sarajevo '' [cited 13 June 2012]] It is the story about a [[Sarajevo]] festival led by Edin Zubcevic and the city of Sarajevo which, despite four years of the brutal [[siege of Sarajevo]], still nourishes multiculturalism and love of jazz music.[http://www.filmfestival-goeast.de/index.php?article_id=228&clang=1&mode=film&event_id=1941/ See Dox: ''A propos de Sarajevo / A propos de Sarajevo '' 11th Sarajevo Film Festival, Festival catalogue, Sarajevo 2005, p. 48. [cited 13 June 2012]] The documentary is 30 minutes long and features E.S.T., Denis Baptist, [[Bojan Zulfikarpašić]] Trio, Dhafer Yousuf, Anuar Brahem and several other European bands. The documentary was screened at [[Sarajevo Film Festival]] (2005) and Bangkok International Film Festival (2006).[http://www.gramofon.ba/releases.php?release_id=23&lang=en/ Gramofon: ''Pasovic Haris - A propos de Sarajevo '' [cited 13 June 2012]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:A propos de Sarajevo}} [[Category:2005 films]] [[Category:Sarajevo]] [[Category:Culture in Sarajevo]] [[Category:Films set in Bosnia and Herzegovina]]
